problems.title: Alice and Bob
problems.statementHtml:
Alice and Bob have a bag with nn marbles, with the integer vivi written on the ii-th marble. They play the following game: first, each player chooses an integer (let's denote the integer chosen by Alice as aa, and the integer chosen by Bob as bb). After that, they start drawing marbles from the bag in any order until the bag is empty. For each ball, the point goes to the one whose chosen integer is closer to the integer on the marble; in case of a tie, Alice gets the point.

For example, if a=10a=10, b=30b=30, then

Bob has managed to find out in advance which integer Alice will choose. Help him to choose his integer in such a way as to maximize the number of points he receives.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases.

Each test case consists of two lines:

  • The first line contains two integers nn and aa (1≤n≤3⋅1051≤n≤3⋅105; 1≤a≤1091≤a≤109) — the number of marbles in the bag and the number chosen by Alice, respectively.
  • The second line contains nn integers v1,v2,…,vnv1,v2,…,vn (1≤v1≤v2≤⋯≤vn≤1091≤v1≤v2≤⋯≤vn≤109).

Additional constraint on the input: the sum of nn across all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer bb (0≤b≤2⋅1090≤b≤2⋅109) that Bob should choose to maximize the number of points he receives. If there are multiple such numbers, you may output any of them.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, if Bob chooses 3535, he gets 55 points for marbles 30,40,50,60,7030,40,50,60,70.

In the third test case, no matter which integer Bob chooses, he gets 00 points.

problems.title: Drifting Away
problems.statementHtml:
There's a river flowing in front of Monocarp's house, which can be represented as a strip of cells. In some cells, there is a strong current, while in others, there is no current. It can be represented as a string ss, consisting of the following characters:

At first, Monocarp chooses the cell to start his journey along the river at.

If there is a current in the cell, where Monocarp is at the moment, he is carried to the neighboring cell in the direction of the current. If there is no neighboring cell (i. e., a leftward current in cell 11 or a rightward current in cell nn), Monocarp ends up on the shore. Each move takes one minute.

If there is no current in the cell, where Monocarp is at the moment, he rows to the neighboring cell on the left or to the neighboring cell on the right. If there is no neighboring cell in the direction where Monocarp decides to row to, he ends up on the shore. Each move also takes one minute.

Monocarp wants to sail along the river for as long as possible. If Monocarp can sail infinitely, print −1−1. Otherwise, print the maximum time Monocarp can sail along the river before ending up on the shore.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases.

The only line of each test case contains a string ss (1≤|s|≤3⋅1051≤|s|≤3⋅105), consisting only of characters '<' (leftward current), '>' (rightward current), '*' (no current). The ASCII codes are 6060, 6262, and 4242, respectively.

An additional constraint on the input: the total length of strings ss over all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output a single integer:

  • −1−1, if Monocarp can sail along the river infinitely;
  • the maximum time Monocarp can sail along the river before ending up on the shore, otherwise.

problems.title: Range Operation
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an integer array aa of length nn.

You can perform the following operation: choose a range [l,r][l,r] (1≤l≤r≤n1≤l≤r≤n) and replace the value of elements al,al+1,…,aral,al+1,…,ar with (l+r)(l+r).

Your task is to calculate the maximum possible total array sum if you can perform the aforementioned operation at most once.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤2n0≤ai≤2n).

Additional constraint on the input: the sum of nn over all test cases doesn't exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print a single integer — the maximum possible total array sum if you can perform the aforementioned operation at most once.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, you can perform the operation on the subarray [3,3][3,3], resulting in the array [2,5,6][2,5,6] and the sum 1313.

In the second example, you don't need to perform any operation.

In the third example, you can perform the operation on the subarray [1,4][1,4], resulting in the array [5,5,5,5][5,5,5,5] and the sum 2020.

In the fourth example, you can perform the operation on the subarray [2,3][2,3], resulting in the array [3,5,5,9,10][3,5,5,9,10] and the sum 3232.

problems.title: Removal of a Sequence (Easy Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The difference between the versions is the constraint on x; in this version, x≤105.

Polycarp has a sequence of all natural numbers from 1 to 1012. He decides to modify this sequence by performing the following action x times:

After that, Polycarp wants to find the k-th number in the remaining sequence or determine that the length of the resulting sequence is less than k.

Help Polycarp solve this problem!

Consider an example. Let x=2, y=3, k=5, then:

The numbers crossed out with a red line were removed after the first operation, and the numbers crossed out with a blue line were removed after the second operation. Thus, the number at position k=5 is the number 10.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤10). The description of the test cases follows.

The only line of each test case contains three integers x, y, k (1≤x≤105, 1≤y,k≤1012).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a positive integer that is at the k-th position in the resulting sequence, or −1 if the length of the resulting sequence is less than k.

problems.title: Removal of a Sequence (Hard Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the hard version of the problem. The difference between the versions is the constraint on xx; in this version, x≤1012x≤1012.

Polycarp has a sequence of all natural numbers from 11 to 10121012. He decides to modify this sequence by performing the following action xx times:

After that, Polycarp wants to find the kk-th number in the remaining sequence or determine that the length of the resulting sequence is less than kk.

Help Polycarp solve this problem!

Consider an example. Let x=2x=2, y=3y=3, k=5k=5, then:

The numbers crossed out with a red line were removed after the first operation, and the numbers crossed out with a blue line were removed after the second operation. Thus, the number at position k=5k=5 is the number 1010.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤101≤t≤10). The description of the test cases follows.

The only line of each test case contains three integers xx, yy, kk (1≤x,y,k≤10121≤x,y,k≤1012).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a positive integer that is at the kk-th position in the resulting sequence, or −1−1 if the length of the resulting sequence is less than kk.

problems.title: Points Selection
problems.statementHtml:
Alice and Bob are playing with points on the XY plane. Initially, there are nn points on the plane: the ii-th point is located at (xi,yi)(xi,yi) and has a cost of cici.

The game consists of two stages:

After that, the game ends and the total score is calculated. The total score of the game is the sum of the costs of the removed points by Alice and the perimeter of the rectangle drawn by Bob. Alice wants to maximize the score, while Bob wants to minimize it.

Determine the total score of the game if both Alice and Bob play optimally.

The perimeter of the rectangle is equal to the sum of the lengths of all its four sides. Therefore, even if the rectangle degenerates into a line segment of length kk, its perimeter will be 2k2k. The perimeter of a rectangle that degenerates into a point is 00.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤3⋅1051≤n≤3⋅105) — the number of points on the plane.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers x1,x2,…,xnx1,x2,…,xn (0≤xi≤10150≤xi≤1015) — the xx-coordinates of the points.

The third line contains nn integers y1,y2,…,yny1,y2,…,yn (0≤yi≤10150≤yi≤1015) — the yy-coordinates of the points.

The fourth line contains nn integers c1,c2,…,cnc1,c2,…,cn (0≤ci≤1090≤ci≤109) — the costs of the points.

Additional constraints on the input:

  • in one test case, all points are pairwise distinct;
  • the total number of points across all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the final score of the game if both Alice and Bob play optimally.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, there is only one point, and Alice cannot remove it. Then Bob constructs the rectangle (1,1)−(1,1)(1,1)−(1,1) with a perimeter of 00.

In the second test case, it is optimal for Alice not to remove any points. Then Bob constructs the rectangle (0,0)−(10,10)(0,0)−(10,10) with a perimeter of 4040.

In the third test case, it is optimal for Alice to remove the first and third points. Then Bob constructs the rectangle (7,3)−(9,3)(7,3)−(9,3) with a perimeter of 44. The total score will be 9+9+4=229+9+4=22.

problems.title: Subsequence Problem
problems.statementHtml:
Given three integers n,m,kn,m,k, as well as kk arrays of integers of lengths l1,l2,…,lkl1,l2,…,lk respectively. We denote the element at position jj in array number ii as ai,jai,j. In each array, all elements are distinct (but may repeat in different arrays).

We call an array bb of length kk beautiful if for each ii from 11 to kk, the element bibi is equal to one of the elements of the array aiai.

We call an array cc perfect if every beautiful array bb can be obtained from array cc by deleting several (possibly zero) elements without changing their order. In other words, array cc is perfect if every beautiful array bb is a subsequence of it.

Your task is to count the number of perfect arrays cc of length nn containing only integers from 11 to mm.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains three integers n,m,kn,m,k (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105; 5≤m≤1085≤m≤108; 2≤k≤n2≤k≤n).

The second line contains kk integers l1,l2,…,lkl1,l2,…,lk (1≤li≤51≤li≤5).

The following kk lines contain the ii-th line with lili distinct integers ai,1,ai,2,…,ai,liai,1,ai,2,…,ai,li (1≤ai,j≤m1≤ai,j≤m).

Additional constraint on the input: the sum of lili does not exceed nn.
problems.outputSpecHtml: Print one integer — the number of perfect arrays of length nn such that they contain only integers from 11 to mm. Since the answer may be very large, output it modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, there are two beautiful arrays: [4,1,4][4,1,4] and [4,1,3][4,1,3]. Only two arrays of length 44 contain both of these arrays as subsequences: [4,1,4,3][4,1,4,3] and [4,1,3,4][4,1,3,4].

In the second example, there is only one beautiful array: [5,2][5,2]. There are 1313 arrays of length 33 with integers from 11 to 55 that contain it as a subsequence.

tutorial.contentHtml:
2169A - Alice and Bob

Idea: Roms

Tutorial

2169A - Alice and Bob

It is never optimal for Bob to choose $$$b = a$$$. So, either $$$b < a$$$, or $$$b > a$$$.

Among all possible $$$b < a$$$, we can show that it is always correct to choose $$$b = a - 1$$$: for every integer $$$v_i < a$$$, $$$a - 1$$$ will be closer to $$$v_i$$$ than $$$a$$$; and for every integer $$$v_i \ge a$$$, $$$a$$$ will always be closer than any $$$b < a$$$. So, if we use $$$b = a - 1$$$, the number of points Bob gets will be equal to the number of marbles having $$$v_i < a$$$; and if we use any $$$b < a - 1$$$, the answer won't become better.

Similarly, if $$$b > a$$$, it is always optimal to choose $$$b = a + 1$$$, and the number of points will be equal to the number of marbles having $$$v_i > a$$$.

So, it is enough to check only $$$b = a-1$$$ and $$$b = a+1$$$. For both of these values of $$$b$$$, the number of points Bob gets can be calculated easily.
